p: Mucidula mucida var . mucida, the “porcelain mushroom”, is commonly found and widespread in Europe including western Russia and typically grows on Fagus [ 10] ( Figure 3). Other varieties, Mucidula mucida var . asiatica and var . venosolamellata, are distributed in Asia. In Japan, M. mucida var . asiatica has been collected from dead trunks and branches of several broad-leaved tree species, while M. mucidula var . venosolamellata usually grows in dead trunks and branches of Fagus crenata [ 52]. The second species in the genus, Mucidula brunneomarginata, is commonly found on rotting hardwood logs. It was first recorded in Russia and has also been documented in Japan [ 10, 53].
